I will start this review in two seperate forms, one for interested newcomers and then the Old Guard.  I will list off the pros first before the cons of this game, Civilization 3 is a different twist of the game than you may be familar with 4 and 5. Go in understanding this switch:  -Its an old game, if you can run the actual game, there should be no real issues.  -Graphically, it's a sound experience and not many real issues, the modding community can find you bug fixes or new skins. Its pleasing regardless and you won't really be let down by this game.  -Combat is similar to Civ 4, simple dice combat where units have health bars going between 3-6, strength and defense stats play their parts and very simple to understand. There are Offensive Units, Defensive Units and Manovuer units, no exceptions and combat is based on these theorectical roles.  -31 Civs that each have 1 unique unit, unless mods are involved. Civ bonuses are general in that they have two traits which give them bonuses which are shared by others, Militaristic, Religious, Industrists, etc.  -Diplomacy is sound and reliable, techs can be traded directly as well as maps, I will faults soon  -Happiness is based per city, with simple factors involved including conscription  -Civfanatics Community and its modding community are lovely and its still alive and well, just no Workshop  The Cons:  -Civ 5 has a prediction based combat, units do no die with one attack on even matches. Not the case for this game, they fight till they die unless they are manovuer units against inf. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t can and will happen, don't cry.  -The AI Diplomacy is very defensive and almost always cautious, wary or spiteful towards you, no exceptions.  -Its really easy to find yourself fighting half the world because of one war, tech trading is enabled so you can find yourself backwater as they maintain amiable relations and trade those tech with one another while they fight you.   -Multiplayer is old, the members are not exactly nub-friendly, I myself was 3 years old when this game came out.  -Game doesn't work for you, you're ♥♥♥♥ed, not much anyone can do for you.  -In my opinion, the hardest Civilization I have every played, it will humble you many times over. In the end it is a Civ-game, you can't really go wrong with trying. It is the game that personally got me into Civilization and its unique-ness will likely find you some memorable gameplay. Hey and if you get the game and love it, I'd always be willing to play with you by e-mail or I might even try GameRanger. Good luck on your adventure To Stand The Test of Time  Returning Civ 3, should you get it on steam? Yes and no, while digital copies are nice, its not any different from the disk. That being said, I prefer it on Steam. I have purchased this game three times, one the authentic Civ III Gold Version, which was outstanding and I loved it. However, eventually I got a new computer and it turns out the disc was ruined. I got the game a third time over E-bay, the only source I could find which remains, this time the Complete. Features were missing and I couldn't even access them no matter what I tried, the conquest files corrupted and Play the World missing. I got a new computer, my current, running Windows 8.1, 4GB RAM and Integrated Graphics. The disc would not load the game, but viola, I found the steam version was the cheapest to begin with. Its the same game as you know, and for me everything was working well. Underneath I will discuss the major steam issues:  -For me at least, Steam Overlay does not appear to work and I wouldn't know how to fix it, it could be a personal issue, I don't know.   -There are serious issues people have with getting this dinosaur game to work on new computers. Win 7 tends to have more compatiability issues with the game than Win 8(.1). Your at risk here, but this is usually the cheapest alternative  -Modding is simple but remember, access the files through the properties tab by right-click the game in the Library Tab  -Multiplayer is not run by Steam servers, nor GameSpy Arcade, it shut down if you haven't followed the game. It is now accessible over GameRanger. I do not know how that works or even attempted to access multiplayer.

Civ 3 Complete on sale for $1.24 so I buy it since I recall how great it was years ago. I am a big fan of Civ 4 & Civ 5 with all the expansions. And I am delaying getting a new PC until I know the system requirements for Civ 6. Still I realize that there was a lot I missed from Civ 3: Artillery that doesn't suffer damage. The people's portraits in the city display (I liked Civ I's full figurines even better). The fashion progression for world leaders and the population. (Nineteenth Century attire looks good on everybody; I don't know why). Single figure unit graphics. And extremely good graphics for the system requirements.  And the world is massive. Civ 5, by giving every unit at least 2mp, really shrank the world.   Units simply gain more hits points on promotion; no decision on how to specialize.  Music that expresses the time frame of the turn. Civ 5's music is just as varied but seems   designed as background music. Of course it all depends on what one wants from a Civ game. But if it goes on sale again for $1.24 that's not much of a gamble.

Are you looking for a Time sink?  Here you are!  This is a basic turned based Real Time Strategy game based around building a civilation from a tribal state to a modern age.  The Charm of this game really comes from your opponates, how they'll mock you, or try to threaten you to give them what they want. You can completely civil, or you can be a thorn in everyone's side, which can get to the point of the entire planet trying to destroy you.  A problem is that the mechanics can be confusing, heck it took me a solid three hours of reading to get a basic grasp on the game. but once you learn it, it's down, and it become second nature.  Another problem, if you can call it one, is that this game will burn hours of your life without your consent, seriously, you will play 4 hours stright and swear it was maybe 30 minutes.  8/10  PROS: Great RTS game play Aged nicely great freedom to choose  CONS: Quite a few things to learn to even start playing Will sink hours without you knowing it.

I didn't give this game a fair try back in the days when it was new. The game was visually an improvement over Civ II, and the interface was actually functional. I just felt the combat system was poorly done, diplomacy didn't feel right, and the game has a few design quirks. Fast forward to now, I decided to buy the complete edition, which updates the game. What I find now is a game that truly stands between the majesty of Civ II and Civ IV. The Civ experience is there, and it's well represented. The graphics haven't aged all that well, and the interface isn't as nice as the later games, but the gameplay remains classic Civ. The complete edition adds the feature of customizing the game in ways never seen before or again in a Civ game, such as turning down (or up) AI aggression. It is a good, cheaper entry into the world of Civ.

The best of the franchise. I started playing the original shortly after it came out, it blew my mind. CIV2 made minor enhancements, but was largely the same game. The first time I played CIV3, I hated it. The strategies I had developed for 1&2 no longer worked (the catapult is quite different, for example) and it took me a few minutes to grok the culture concept. Once I did (and learned the unit differences), I never went back. The AI is sooo much better than before and unlike CIV4 (which despite buying and forcing myself to play, I never enjoyed), you still get to micromanage a great deal (but you can also automate quite a bit - the ability to choose is awesome). Buy it on sale if new to the franchise & start with a tiny world. If you are used to another CIV game, don't wait for a sale, buy it now & get to know the differences in the tech tree as well as the unit differences - I bet you'll like it!

For a game made all the way back in October 2001, this is a fantastic game.  First off, if you bought Civilization Revolution for the Xbox 360 or iPad, that is nothing compared to this old but fantastic game. Secondly, make sure you play this when you havn't got anything else to do in the next 24 hours because this game takes some time and patients and you are guranteed to get 100% addicted. However, if you want to go online, nobody will be on there and if you host a server nobody will join (unless, of course, one of your friends have the game and you invite them). Also, on your first game you ever play, make sure you make it so it's on the easiest difficulty and do a little amount of Civilizations otherwise you will get brutally battered like a Cod fish.  10 features Civilization 3 has that Civilization Revolution Doesn't  1. You can alter the map size between Tiny and Huge. 2. You can alter the settings on how to win the game. 3. The Middle Age is included. 4. You get workers to build Outposts, Mines, Barricades, Irrigation (farm/food resources) etc. 5. There is more research. 6. More units. 7. Create your own map in the editor. 8. Edit the map properties. 9. More Civilizations. 10. More Civilizations allowed to be active in game.  Keep in mind that Civilization Revolution is newer than Civilization 3. I can't really think of anything you can't do in Civilization 3 that you can in Civilization Revolution. I cannot compare Civilization 3 to Civilization 2, 4 and 5 as I do not have those and I have never played them. I would assume that Civilization 4 and 5 are better though. I completely reccomend this game and I'd say it is still a brilliant game now in 2014 and that takes a lot for a game to be that good!  Hope this makes you want to buy Civilization 3 because it deserves more buyers. This game is also very handy if you have have a bad Graphics Card and Processor like my computer. When it says it runs on Windows XP only it really means Windows XP or better. Happy Gaming!

Civ 3 is a classic, turn-based, strategy game that pretty much set the standard for this sort of game. Time has passed, and there are newer games that you can play (including newer Civilization games), but for those who played this one: it still holds a place in their hearts.  For those who have never played this one, you can probably skip this edition. Not only are there many things that feel dated, but the newer Civ games refine this formula in almost every way, making this one obsolete.  --- No score ---

I purchased this game in order to understand and have an enlightenment on the essential game mechanics of the Civilization game series. I am still not sure whether Civilization III was the right choice.  Here are a few topics that I wish to highlight: - It is a low-paced, turn-based strategy game with a significant amount of historical content. - There are a few variables in the game that the person should learn before starting to play. Luckily, steam provides us with a manual, so DO read it. - For beginners, this game may become tough, even at the lowest difficulty setting. Even after learning the basics, there are many things one can do wrong. - This game can take MANY hours of your time, and once your civilization has more than 10 settlements, it may take more than a minute to play each game turn. In addition, there may be dozens and dozens of turns before a victory condition is met. - Although it DOES seem to work on my Windows 8.1 machine, there are a few frustrating issues, such as window switching not restoring the original resolution until the game is terminated. Also, the game may occasionally crash on some particular user, and so far it has always crashed after the end of a game. This means that the game could have had a better preparation for modern systems.  Therefore, it is both hard to recommend and unrecommend this game. Take this as a midline evaluation.
